6C29FA81147540ACAB2081E14ED67D52.description: EK 5.3B1: Reflection acknowledges the impact of actions on both the group and individual contributions, noting the reasons for such actions, assumptions made, and whether or not such actions and assumptions hindered or helped the achievement of the group’s and individuals’ tasks.

2B3159D11E494ED7B9D6638CE2CA00D7.description: LO 5.3B: Reflecting on personal contributions to overall collaborative effort.

A1657FE3692941E1BDCCB4BD3C4CC8DB.description: EK 5.3A2: Learning requires practice through an iterative process of thinking/rethinking, vision/revision, and writing/rewriting

381DEA9055194B6F925E8358EA118230.description: EK 5.3A1: Reflection is an ongoing and recursive process in inquiry, often leading to changes in understanding. Strategies for reflection may include journal writing, self-questioning, drawing, exploration of space, and/or guided contemplation

61B16CF2B5854967A2551C369FD07F02.description: LO 5.3A: Reflecting on and revising their own writing, thinking, and creative processes.

3EAA0DF64C75413899F707B50EC90034.description: EU 5.3: Reflection increases learning, self-awareness, and personal growth through identification and evaluation of personal conclusions and their implications.

4015D73F275040BD8AEDBBFA85F4654F.description: EK 5.2B4: Effective teams consider the use of online collaborative tools.

ABAAC1CCA45B476982BD86F80D01C098.description: EK 5.2B3: Teams function at their best when they practice effective interpersonal communication, consensus building, conflict resolution, and negotiation.

582EA3371688449CBF2A577F893A243A.description: EK 5.2B2: Teams function at their best when they understand the diversity of their social–cultural perspectives, talents, and skills.

C56F0F51224F4521A34B6D040158E7C4.description: EK 5.2B1: Teams are built around tasks. Low-risk teambuilding activities and simulations enhance a team’s performance.

59818B4DD45F439F84E0B7F20C67299C.description: LO 5.2B: Fostering constructive team climate, resolving conflicts, and facilitating the contributions of all team members to address complex, open-ended problems.

AEC31A7ABCC84A4493DF40213B0D6944.description: EK 5.2A1: Knowing and communicating one’s strengths and challenges to a group allows one’s contributions to be more effective.

FC9778C94CB04DE19B1DB2FA6578E582.description: LO 5.2A: Providing individual contributions to overall collaborative effort to accomplish  a task or goal.

ED8B4D88432042408EFCF0756E9FBF34.description: EU 5.2: Teams are most effective when they draw on the diverse perspectives, skills, and backgrounds of team members to address complex, open-ended problems

1E8C767E0C8B41ECB0A8F66F01A34908.description: EK 5.1E1: Speakers vary elements of delivery (e.g., volume, tempo, movement, eye contact, vocal variety, energy) to emphasize information, convey tone, and engage their audience.

D40187A146334FE59499F297327D09F1.description: LO 5.1E: Engaging an audience by employing effective techniques of delivery or performance.

67414B727F374B0AB7F193CF45F6720B.description: EK 5.1D1: Arguments can be adapted by strategically selecting and emphasizing information considering audience, situation, medium and purpose.

88A41594936C445EA48684C646B3D6C6.description: LO 5.1D: Adapting an argument for context, purpose, and/or audience.

A2F4F5BCFCEE4F7A8A702C4A020BE3CF.description: EK 5.1C3: Effective communication requires choosing appropriate media (e.g., essay, poster, oral presentation, documentary, research report/thesis) according to context, purpose, and audience.

5E2A58F966874186BB99C854380C6576.description: EK 5.1C2: Data and other information can be presented graphically (e.g., infographics, graphs, tables, models) to aid audience understanding and interpretation.

CE8504C9BE1A4056BC167BB22831672D.description: EK 5.1C1: Effective organizational and design elements (e.g., headings, layout, illustrations, pull quotes, captions, lists) may aid in audience engagement and understanding by calling attention to important information and/or creating emotional responses in the audience. Ineffective use or overuse of these elements disrupts audience engagement and understanding.

CCC6BB1E9FF44E58A687D19A9724A1B5.description: LO 5.1C: Communicating information using effective techniques of design.

2FED0FE2D9744236A6499AFA0405EEEA.description: EK 5.1B4: Spelling and grammar errors detract from credibility.

98A8C1D9A5D346D2A27D0200B19F5218.description: EK 5.1B3: Precision in word choice reduces confusion, wordiness, and redundancy.

A29EE309F820408194AC585AA1F9F56E.description: EK 5.1B2: Effective sentences create variety, emphasis, and interest through structure, agreement of elements, placement of modifiers, and consistency of tense.

26AFD652C50440A69CA04BA77392DFEF.description: EK 5.1B1: A writer expresses tone or attitude about a topic through word choice, sentence structure, and imagery.

BAF3BFE881A54C9CB7A4318F30063DB7.description: LO 5.1B: Adhering to established conventions of grammar, usage, style, and mechanics.

9DB6439AD0CB49FA95938F89BA2ECC34.description: EK 5.1A2: Coherence is achieved when the elements and ideas in an argument flow logically and smoothly. Transitions are used to move the audience from one element or idea to another by illustrating the relationship between the elements or ideas.

1D09BCADFC1E4C0F91C11E83B58FC594.description: EK 5.1A1: An argument may include the following elements: introduction; thesis; reasons, evidence, and commentary; counterargument, concession, refutation, and rebuttal; conclusion; bibliography.

1286201ECF0E4C8AA8C8A1EE67E1FDD7.description: LO 5.1A: Planning, producing, and presenting a cohesive argument, considering audience, context, and purpose, and using appropriate media (e.g., essay, poster, presentation, documentary, research report/thesis).

1AB1433AE68E412EAB9656D2B7343B5C.description: EU 5.1: How a perspective or argument is presented affects how people interpret or react to it. The same perspective or argument may be developed and presented differently depending on audience, purpose, and context.

C9FD1743505E4F97BB1C937AF41DE897.description: EK 4.5A1: When proposing a solution, the advantages and disadvantages of the options and alternatives should be weighed against the goal within its context.

6A08CBF5CD2B4142A65AC19CA9D227A6.description: LO 4.5A: Offering resolutions, conclusions, and/or solutions based on evidence as well as considering consequences and implications.

579DFD8FC8A44FC68CD52234D51026E5.description: EU 4.5: Arguments, choices, and solutions present intended and unintended opportunities, consequences, and implications.

23EF9FBA34F34494AC077A899F11796E.description: EK 4.4A1: Innovative solutions and arguments identify and challenge assumptions, acknowledge the importance of content, imagine and explore alternatives, and engage in reflective skepticism.

64A96D450F8D4AFF8BD42E8F058B17B7.description: LO 4.4A: Extending an idea, question, process, or product to innovate or create new understandings.

02D4FF0AC1F14E0E9521FB978B16FE42.description: EU 4.4: Forming one’s own perspective and reaching new understandings involve innovative thinking and synthesis of existing knowledge with personally generated evidence.

6218CCFB80BA4D018BB69EEC5D4BA51E.description: EK 4.3A5: Academic disciplines use specific style guides for citing and attributing sources (e.g., APA, MLA, Chicago, AMA).

96DEF547A3A14D3F89C9519F5026DA4B.description: EK 4.3A4 Quoted and paraphrased material must be properly attributed, credited, and cited following a style manual. Quoting is using the exact words of others; paraphrasing is restating an idea in your own words.

243BEFBB9D444CC78BFD925D98812C28.description: EK 4.3A3: Source material should be introduced, integrated, or embedded into the text of an argument.

7BE25A983F624C25A653A7F51B7966EB.description: EK 4.3A2: Plagiarism is a serious offense that occurs when a person presents another’s ideas or words as his or her own. Plagiarism may be avoided by acknowledging sources thoroughly and accurately.

3CD32E5E27874E709E2F81052B975398.description: EK 4.3A1: Accurate and ethical attribution enhances one’s credibility.

106575F99D3A4EC282D4135DB8E73AEF.description: LO 4.3A: Attributing knowledge and ideas accurately and ethically, using an appropriate citation style.

20383B47EBB54ABB925CADEE3BCC409B.description: EU 4.3: Responsible participation in the scholarly community requires acknowledging and respecting the prior findings and contributions of others.

0FE75FCB214149E3BE04FAC8CC6C40D2.description: EK 4.2B1: Commentary connects the chosen evidence to the claim through interpretation or inference, identifying patterns, describing trends, and/or explaining relationships (e.g., comparative, causal, correlational).

80470747D8854CA4B8DCAC77F3F7F968.description: LO 4.2B: Providing insightful and cogent commentary that links evidence with claims.

1D64D1D340B3437C8CBF3C0F7C2197C5.description: EK 4.2A4: The evidence selected and attributed contributes to establishing the credibility of one’s own argument.

15D3625B0ADC417BA5113D887726F15A.description: EK 4.2A3: Evidence is strategically chosen based on context, purpose and audience. Evidence may be used to align an argument with authority; to define a concept, illustrate a process, or clarify a statement; to set a mood; to provide an example; to amplify or qualify a point.

58FE4DB26F1941E8B4F8E7A0B7D96A7E.description: EK 4.2A2: Evidence is used to support the claims and reasoning of an argument. Compelling evidence should be sufficient, accurate, relevant, current, and credible to support the conclusion.

B286ED0C53D3455AA6C4433165C330D4.description: EK 4.2A1: Evidence can be collected from print and nonprint sources (e.g., libraries, museums, archives), experts, or data gathered in the field (e.g., interviews, questionnaires, observations).

22E4D8F0FCD84C4095113DCED6A4E2CD.description: LO 4.2A: Interpreting, using, and synthesizing qualitative and/or quantitative data/information from various perspectives and sources (e.g., primary, secondary, print, nonprint) to develop and support an argument.

F2C9AABB70564DC9B20D819777AD87AF.description: EU 4.2: Scholars responsibly and purposefully engage with the evidence to develop a compelling argument or aesthetic rationale.

424430C409C0498C834E3B7F02228AE2.description: EK 4.1A9: The same argument may be organized, arranged, or supported in multiple ways depending on audience and context.

D56CFD2FAA2544F38B386B538F3A0CAC.description: EK 4.1A8: Claims and supporting evidence are arranged (e.g., spatially, chronologically, order of importance) to convey reasoning and relationship (e.g., comparative, causal, correlational).

0279109297864A938D54B6BF4E464DC6.description: EK 4.1A7: A line of reasoning is organized based on the argument’s purpose (e.g., to show causality, to evaluate, to define, to propose a solution).

A584C4D3CBD64E9C8880EC3861EDE819.description: EK 4.1A6: The logic and reasoning of an argument may be deductive (claim followed by evidence) or inductive (evidence leads to a conclusion).

C2F259A5F8B0468292EFDC881826E386.description: EK 4.1A5: The line of reasoning is a clear, logical, sequential path leading the audience through the reasons towards a conclusion.

901BB3DF3FEB42439368165E6ECB9DD5.description: EK 4.1A4: Effective arguments acknowledge other arguments and/or respond to them with counterarguments (e.g., via concession, refutation, and/or rebuttal).

D491186B50944C5CAD1E3555279EBC9A.description: EK 4.1A3: Qualifiers place limits on how far a claim may be carried. Effective arguments acknowledge these limits, increasing credibility by reducing overgeneralization or oversimplification.

C0EA14E5D6984AD8875B0FA2473FADFC.description: EK 4.1A2: Effective arguments are supported and unified by carefully chosen and connected claims, reasons, and evidence.

7EEFCAF1CDA74D75AAC5B9882BF59DB9.description: EK 4.1A1: Effective arguments use reason and evidence to convey a perspective, point of view, or some version of the truth that is stated or implied in the thesis and/or conclusion.

05F0ACFDEAB34DA8B8418482101B57D0.description: LO 4.1A: Formulating a well-reasoned argument, taking the complexities of the problem or issue into consideration.

2095FE7D036147CA9A84665E018D35B4.description: EU: 4.1: Scholarly works convey perspectives and demonstrate effective lines of reasoning that have been selected for the intended audience, purpose, and situation.

234AA6D78C37408E8C3E774BC26C6ED2.description: EK 3.2A2: When evaluating multiple perspectives or arguments, consideration must be given to how one's own personal biases and assumptions can influence one's judgment.

F199BB0077694783BF8D62876F99FE4D.description: EK 3.2A1: Critical thinkers are aware that some arguments may appeal to emotions, core values, personal biases and assumptions, and logic.

20C12B7238D04A64A42B280029B443D5.description: LO 3.2A: Evaluating alternate, opposing, or competing perspectives or arguments, by considering their implications and limitations.

FC99F8C9D1EA4E8C8F5FA7EE54D178B4.description: EU 3.2: Not all arguments are equal; some arguments are more credible/valid than others. Through evaluating others’ arguments, one’s own arguments can be situated within a larger conversation.

ED261574601E4A71B2D72C1ED250B4E2.description: EK 3.1A2: Perspectives are not always oppositional; they may be concurring, complementary, or competing.

388FF97801B64CBF9128E1F462EE8FC6.description: EK 3.1A1: An individual’s perspective is influenced by his or her background (e.g., experiences, culture, education), assumptions, and world view, as well as by external sources.

3AFBE810A4864BF8B3107DD32E9A241C.description: LO 3.1A: Identifying, comparing, and interpreting multiple perspectives on or arguments about an issue.

03604C1355F24B5CAF247CE750D1D0A5.description: EU 3.1: Different perspective often lead to competing and alternate arguments. The complexity of an issue emerges when people bring these differing multiple perspective to the conversation.

399D8AD038064F1C9FF55C23722B35CB.description: EK 2.3B1: Arguments are significant and have real-world impact because they can influence behavior (e.g., call one to action, suggest logical next steps).

E3472CAEAED749E6B4B2BB0BF9D9AB10.description: LO 2.3B: Evaluating potential resolutions, conclusions, or solutions to problems or issues in an argument.

08980A9BAD70434BA96997E5B2EDF9F7.description: EK 2.3A1: The implications and consequences of arguments may be intended or unintended.

102FC11A42E04BEAB0E62AC72B4C3794.description: LO 2.3A: Connecting an argument to broader issues by examining the implications of the author’s claim.

3363594BCA1A4177853F9EC41DB8ED64.description: EU 2.3: Arguments have implications and consequences.

4628882743594F4E9821251E62782139.description: EK 2.2C1: An argument is valid when there is logical alignment between the line of reasoning and the conclusion.

98AF0B63A7E34C298352BC71CAB05069.description: LO 2.2C: Evaluating the validity of an argument.

D0E27EF129DD4E7AB1C4EAD5551CEB8A.description: EK 2.2B6: Credibility is compromised when authors fail to acknowledge and/or consider the limitations of their conclusions, opposing views or perspectives, and/or their own biases.

F164B677097949609D64AF7E9EF53FB6.description: EK 2.2B5: Evidence may be used to identify and explain relationships (comparative, causal, or correlational) and/or patterns and trends.

B1E3E8EFD69A4F4497F755794062CA42.description: EK 2.2B4: Writers appeal to (or possibly manipulate) readers through a variety of strategies and techniques (e.g., language, authority, qualifiers, fallacies, emphasis).

D7A3D53A3FF74081BCF07ADF52C8E002.description: EK 2.2B3: Authors strategically include evidence to support their claims.

667C53C934DC41EE9664E6F6CDD64377.description: EK 2.2B2: Writers use qualitative and/or quantitative evidence (e.g., facts, data, observations, predictions, analogies, explanations, opinions) to support their claims. Evidence has varying degrees of validity.

274C174AA4C0461C983BE3317AF7E085.description: EK 2.2B1: An argument’s context (time and purpose) and situation (relation to the other related arguments) inform its interpretation.

B09849EC4CF444E4874FC3296354D586.description: LO 2.2B: Evaluating  the relevance and credibility of evidence used to support an argument, taking context into consideration.

2E6CCBA668484DF49560EFB4359FC115.description: EK 2.2A5: Effective arguments acknowledge other arguments and/or respond to them with counterarguments (e.g.,concession, refutation, rebuttal).

E18F612BC9114C9BA95FCC73E2A3A2CE.description: EK2.2A4: A lack of understanding of the complexities of an argument (tone, implications, limitations, nuance, context) can lead to oversimplification and/or generalization.

A8B4FFF303714A6F90DC8054CD964843.description: EK 2.2A3: Inductive reasoning uses specific observations and/or data points to identify trends, make generalizations, and draw conclusions. Deductive reasoning uses broad facts or generalizations to generate additional, more specific conclusions about a phenomenon.

07CDA9FD2D2F48B5AFB55E89EA33192A.description: EK 2.2A2: An argument’s line of reasoning is organized based on the argument’s purpose (e.g., to show causality, to define, to propose a solution).

C6F8F2165EDB4998B8DE28E9B01C287B.description: EK 2.2A1: Authors use reasons to support their arguments. The line of reasoning is composed of one or more claims justified through evidence.

E25B1C7A504B4574B3DB73FC9143D2B6.description: LO 2.2A: Explaining and analyzing the logic and line of reasoning of an argument.

7DF68E60F16F43CB870B69C30A3A8AF7.description: EU 2.2: Authors choose evidence to shape and support their arguments. Individuals evaluate the line of reasoning and evidence to determine to what extent they believe or accept an argument.

C835B565763B43A98BAB231BDAEF9D93.description: EK 2.1B2: Artistic works (e.g., painting, film, music, dance) convey a perspective. Analysis of a work’s context, subject, structure, style, and aesthetic is critical to understanding its aims.

F6B91611A8E9429D8F173875F6943B06.description: EK 2.1B1: The main idea of an argument is often stated in the thesis statement, claim, or conclusion, or implied throughout a work.

30AB0373D3824142A346AE06C0916C8E.description: LO 2.1B: Summarizing and explaining a text’s main idea or aim while avoiding faulty generalizations and oversimplification.

DA7DDDD5FDF54375A4ED25663511B0F1.description:
EK 2.1A4: Perspectives are shared through written, spoken, visual, or performance texts. A perspective includes the writer’s attitude/tone regarding the subject and is expressed
through an argument.

5DA8DBF345E9431F85727F9ACAF721BD.description: EK 2.1A3: Strategies active readers use to make meaning from texts include annotating, note-taking, highlighting, and reading aloud.

C6F697AD3CFA4076B88263D655A3495D.description: EK 2.1A2: Strategies active readers use to preview and prioritize a written text include skimming, scanning, rereading, and questioning.

C30DED9FA43944E9AF5A1AFBD2C349B3.description: EK 2.1A1: Reading critically means reading closely to identify the main idea, tone, assumptions, context, perspective, line of reasoning, and evidence used.

0120E389EC0547C98D3941A3F2A91D8C.description: LO 2.1A: Employing appropriate reading strategies and reading critically for a specific purpose.

23BE21D818CE4C32BE61167DD0F36040.description: EU 2.1: Authors express their ideas, perspectives and/or arguments through their works. The first step in evaluating an author’s perspective or argument is to comprehend it. Such comprehension requires reading, viewing, listening, and thinking critically.

7793110384214177AF732B71CA3AC9BC.description: EK 1.5A1: The way the problem is posed, situated, framed, or contextualized will guide the inquiry process and influence the type of information needed and the appropriate method of gathering it.

058EE526489643E0B5EA554543BAA5C1.description: LO 1.5A: Identifying the information needed for the context of the inquiry.

5F3E4E4FADCD4FE0ADABB74085317313.description: EU 1.5: There are multiple ways to investigate questions, problems and issues. Methods should be aligned with the purpose of the inquiry.

BD037BCCB6BC4BED82730940DE6AA3FB.description: EK 1.4A3: Determining the credibility of a source requires considering and evaluating the reputation and credentials of the author, publisher, site owner, and/or sponsor; understanding and evaluating the author’s perspective and research methods; and considering how others respond to their work. Scholarly articles are often peer reviewed, meaning the research has been reviewed and accepted by disciplinary experts.

136FE6B276724650A490601FBAE68738.description: EK 1.4A2: Credibility of evidence depends on use of sources and data that are relevant and reliable (current, authoritative).

4A2D810D5FA14E9186FB470D5D2DF258.description: EK 1.4A1: The scope and purpose of one's research and the credibility of sources affects the generalizability and the reliability of the conclusion(s).

70B487A02F364AB7A27EEAF66AAEE06A.description: LO 1.4A: Evaluating the relevance and credibility of the source of information and date in relation to the inquiry.

8CD7A9F74F294D92AC60C85243B677B2.description: EU 1.4: The relevance and credibility of the source of information is determined by the context of its use.

1B365520E47C47E495557D2B79C5A6B1.description: EK 1.3A3: Advanced search tools, Boolean logic, and key words allow researchers to refine, focus, and/or limit their searches based on a variety of factors (e.g., date, peer- review status, type of publication).

AB5FE1D5FBD14A3694E792791658B39C.description: EK 1.3A2: Online databases (e.g., EBSCO,ProQuest, JSTOR, Google Scholar) and libraries catalog and house secondary and some primary sources.

948616C01FE642D7A3D3DFD3E3C13D7A.description: EK 1.3A1: Information used to address a problem may come from various secondary sources (e.g., articles, other studies, analyses, reports) and/or primary sources (e.g., original texts and works, material culture, or personally collected data such as form experiments, surveys, questionnaires, interviews , observations, personal narratives).

2D38852930334D64B2FD21BB8F2BFB52.description: LO 1.3A: Accessing and managing information using effective strategies.

9487AF4F58BA4111BE8E0C1D8A894DA7.description: EU 1.3: The investigative process is aided by the effective organization, management, and selection of resources and information. Appropriate technologies and tools enable the scholar to become more efficient, productive, and credible

C61957EBF33047F5B5E4D61D6CD3CDF0.description: EK 1.2A3: Inquiry confirms or challenges one’s existing understandings, assumptions, beliefs, and/or knowledge.

550EDD6FDAA5411B9C3A7EBDEA9E92A5.description: EK 1.2A2: A variety of strategies (e.g., brainstorming, concept mapping, prewriting, exploration of space, drafting) can be used to illustrate, organize, and connect ideas.

1406143DA8234C5FACA105703C2B8BF0.description: EK 1.2A1: Understanding comes not only through collection of information but also from a variety of other factors (e.g., experience, external sources, culture, assumptions).

3C20DA82404740A4BEBBA66850D1D6E0.description: LO 1.2A: Retrieving, questioning, organizing, and using prior knowledge about a topic.

5FE5A3E3CC40475F8BC689470226398F.description: EU 1.2: Strengthening understanding of a concept or issue requires questioning existing ideas, using what is known to discover what is not known, and making connections to prior knowledge.

0EC420E806AE4D3AB5101FDFE36CDF15.description: EK 1.1B2: The inquiry process allows one to draw upon curiosity and imagination to engage with ideas or explore approaches to complex issues.

30F5EE410E654C22BB776763AE34EBFF.description: EK 1.1B1: Effective research questions are open-ended and lead to an examination, taking into account the complexity of a problem or issue.

30D6996BB0F54EB4899192C1588D84BD.description: LO 1.1B: Posing questions and seeking out answers that reflect multiple, divergent, or contradictory perspectives

A65131D4AF9642288F766D37CC0185B0.description: EK 1.1A1: Examining the perspectives and ideas of others often leads to questions for further investigation. Inquiry begins with narrowing scope of interest, identifying a problem or issue and its origin within that scope, and situating the problem or issue in a larger context.

1D940F6131794E088F063B6058DA878C.description: LO 1.1A: Contextualizing and identifying the complexities of a problem or issue.

E0D8A380A200410FAAD3F0F082159E15.description: EU 1.1: Personal interest and intellectual curiosity inspire investigation of topics or issues that may or may not be clearly defined. A well crafted investigation explores the complexity of an issue or topic. Further inquiry can lead to unexpected conclusions, resolutions, innovations, or solution.
